Arling | editing = Harold F. Kress | distributor = [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]] | released = {{start date|1955|12|25}} | runtime = 117 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = $6.5 million (US)<ref>'The Top Box-Office Hits of 1956', ''Variety Weekly'', January 2, 1957</ref> | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''I'll Cry Tomorrow''''' ([[1955 in film|1955]]) is a [[biopic]] which tells the story of [[Lillian Roth]], a [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] star who rebels against the pressure of her domineering mother and reacts to the death of her fiancÃ© by becoming an alcoholic. It stars [[Susan Hayward]], [[Richard Conte]], [[Eddie Albert]], [[Margo (actress)|Margo]], and [[Jo Van Fleet]]. The [[screenplay]] was adapted by [[Helen Deutsch]] and [[Jay Richard Kennedy]] from the autobiography by Lillian Roth, [[Mike Connolly (columnist)|Mike Connolly]] and [[Gerold Frank]]. It was directed by [[Daniel Mann]]. It won the [[Academy Award for Costume Design]] for [[Helen Rose]], and was nominated for [[Academy Award for Best Actress|Best Actress in a Leading Role]] (Susan Hayward), [[Academy Award for Best Art Direction|Best Art Direction-Set Decoration, Black-and-White]] ([[Cedric Gibbons]], [[Malcolm Brown (art director)|Malcolm Brown]], [[Edwin B. Willis]], [[Hugh B. Hunt]]) and [[Academy Award for Best Cinematography|Best Cinematography, Black-and-White]].<ref name="NY Times">{{cite web |url=http://movies.nytimes.com/movie/24168/I-ll-Cry-Tomorrow/details |title=NY Times: I'll Cry Tomorrow |accessdate=2008-12-22|work=NY Times}}</ref> It was also entered into the [[1956 Cannes Film Festival]].<ref name="festival-cannes.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.festival-cannes.com/en/archives/ficheFilm/id/3595/year/1956.html |title=Festival de Cannes: I'll Cry Tomorrow |accessdate=2009-02-03|work=festival-cannes.com}}</ref> ==Reviews== "[[Susan Hayward]] sings for the first time on the screen, and will win much applause for her throaty voice in such songs as ''[[Sing, You Sinners (song)|Sing, You Sinners]]'', ''[[When the Red, Red Robin (Comes Bob, Bob, Bobbin' Along)]]'', and ''[[I'm Sitting on Top of the World]]''. She is supported by [[Ray Danton]] as the man whose death first upsets her; by [[Jo Van Fleet]] as her domineering mother who realises what she has done too late; Richard Conte, Eddie Albert and Don Taylor." <ref> ''Picture Show'', June 23, 1956 </ref> ==Cast== [[Image:Susan Hayward and Eddie Albert.jpg|right|250px|thumb|Susan Hayward and Eddie Albert]] * [[Susan Hayward]] as Lillian Roth * [[Richard Conte]] as Tony Bardeman * [[Eddie Albert]] as Burt McGuire * [[Jo Van Fleet]] as Katie Roth * [[Don Taylor (actor)|Don Taylor]] as Wallie * [[Ray Danton]] as David Tredman * [[Margo (actress)|Margo]] as Selma * [[Virginia Gregg]] as Ellen * [[Don 'Red' Barry]] as Jerry * [[David Kasday]] as David as a child * [[Carole Ann Campbell]] as Lillian (a child) * [[Peter Leeds]] as Richard Elstead * [[Tol Avery]] as Joe - drunk party guest * [[Anthony Jochim]] as Paul (butler) * [[Jack Daley]] as Cab driver * [[Ralph Edwards]] as Himself (uncredited) ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category}} * {{imdb title|id=0048191|title=I'll Cry Tomorrow}} *[http://www.filmscoremonthly.com/cds/detail.cfm/CDID/303/Ill-Cry-Tomorrow/ Sound samples of the film score] {{Daniel Mann}} [[Category:1955 films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:Films directed by Daniel Mann]] [[Category:Biographical films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer films]] [[Category:Black-and-white films]] {{bio-film-stub}}
